ygData.subject: Re: Financial trading with Hyperneat

Hey Peter,

I think I missed a step here. How is the data planetary coordin=
ates? From the excel sheet, it looks like there are only a handful of input=
s.

Jason G.

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Peter Henry <blackprinzze@...> w=
rote:
>
> Hello Peter,
> 
> Yes it does make sense to try NEAT first, just =
to get a feel for this. The main 
> reason I considered hyperNEAT is becaus=
e the input data would be planetary 
> coordinates, of which is geometric i=
n nature. The inputs should total no more 
> than 40, this also includes in=
ter-market forex data. Because future planetary 
> information is known in =
advance this can be used in our forecasts.
> 
> Which source data Library d=
o you feel is best for this type of task?
> 
> Peter 
> 
> 
>

> From: petar_chervenski <petar_chervenski@...>

 To: neat@yahoogroups.com

[neat] Re: Financial trading with Hyperneat

> =C2=A0 
> Hi Peter, 
> 
> =
I'd suggest that you try regular NEAT first, HyperNEAT may not be neccessar=
y. 
> HyperNEAT is a good choice if the inputs are hundreds or thousands in=
 number 
> and/or there is some obvious geometry in the input space that ca=
n be exploited 
> by arranging the positions of the substrate nodes. For fi=
nancial applications 
> I'd use a small set of inputs, but very preprocesse=
d data, like what most good 
> custom indicators do, and regular NEAT. 
> 
=
> 
> Peter
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Wesley Tansey <tansey@> wrote:=

> >
> > Peter,
> > 
> > I think you'd be better off familiarizing yourself=
 with the details of 
> > how HyperNEAT works. Novelty Search is a differen=
t algorithm altogether, 
> > for a different class of problems. You probabl=
y should familiarize 
> > yourself with the HyperNEAT algorithm before tryi=
ng to design an 
> > experiment. The HyperNEAT user's page has a lot of rea=
lly good 
> > information: http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/hyperNEATpage/HyperNEAT.=
html
> > 
> > I'm not familiar with the EPlex's C++ framework, but SharpNEA=
T does 
> > provide a GUI. However, it's more of an engineer's GUI, designe=
d to 
> > visualize your experiment after you set it up in code. I tend to =
find it 
> > easier to just use SharpNEAT in a console application. I've wr=
itten some 
> > tutorials on how to create a SharpNEAT experiment:
> > 
> >=
http://www.nashcoding.com/2010/07/17/tutorial-evolving-neural-networks-with=
-sharpneat-2-part-1/
> >/
> > 
> > Hope that helps.
> > 
> > Sincerely,
> >=
 Wesley
> >

 ?

oups.com <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com>, Wesley

ote:

> > > > I think if you normalize you=
r data (e.g., in the range [-1,1]), you can
> > > > certainly give it a sho=
t. You need to be careful about overfitting to
> > > > your data, especiall=
y when all you have is daily data. Also, you 
> > > need to
> > > > be caut=
ious about the fact that you'd be trading a black box.

ds like a fun project though, best of luck!
